title: Five of the best cruise lines for family holidays at sea
text:
Five of the best cruise lines for family holidays at sea Five of the best cruise lines for family holidays at sea SWIMMING pools and water parks, free children’s clubs and activities, family cabins and teenagers’ hang-outs – pick the right cruise line and you can have it all. PUBLISHED: 19:29, Mon, Jul 13, 2015 | UPDATED: 19:58, Mon, Jul 13, 2015 PH Swimming pool on the Azura 
Royal Caribbean International 
There are children’s clubs for every age, starting with Royal Babies (6-18 months but parents must attend) and Royal Tots (18-36 months, with parents) and followed by three Adventure Ocean age groups up to 11 then Tween and Teen groups. 
Organised activities include the Adventure Ocean Youth Programme, which includes educational subjects like the science behind sailing, sports activities and learning about the ports they will be visiting. 
But if your children don’t like clubs there are lots of other activities, from pools and water parks to sports courts. 
And RCI ships are renowned for their onboard facilities: Ripcord by iFly skydiving on the latest ships plus FlowRider surfing and climbing walls on most and ice rinks on some of the ships. 
Evening entertainment ranges from the hit musical Mamma Mia! on Quantum of the Seas to We Will Rock You on Anthem of the Seas, which is based in Southampton this summer. 
More information at www.royalcaribbean.co.uk 
Princess Cruises 
Children’s programmes include activities provided by the California Science Centre, and the opportunity to learn about endangered species such as sea turtles and manatees. 
New for this year is a partnership with the Discovery Channel, offering exciting activities for the whole family including Discovery Recommended shore excursions and experiences such as Stargazing at Sea, “Shark Week” and the Princess Culinary Academy. 
All the cruise line’s ships have clubs for all ages and its newest, Royal Princess and Regal Princess, have a teens-only outdoor space for sunbathing and parties, as well as an indoor lounge with a DJ booth, hip-hop dance classes and video games. 
Movies Under The Stars remains a favourite for all the family, who can lie out on loungers to watch blockbuster movies on a huge screen beside the main pool. 
Complimentary popcorn, warm cookies and milk are handed out at evening shows with fleecy blankets for late screenings. 
Princess Cruises also has its own Caribbean island, Princess Cays, where children can use a supervised play area, Pelican Perch, while their parents enjoy the beach. 
More information at www.princess.com Climbing wall on Royal Caribbean cruise ship 
P&O Cruises 
This year’s new ship Britannia has a teenagers-only outdoor space for 13 to 17-year-olds as well as an indoor hangout with state-of-the-art video game zones. 
In all there are four age group clubs on P&O’s family ships Aurora, Azura, Oceana, Ventura and Britannia. 
These clubs start from Splashers (2-4 years) and an early children’s tea is available every night so that parents can eat alone if they prefer, although parents are expected to supervise. 
Free 30-minute Cookery Club Kids Classes during school holidays are part of the children’s activities on Britannia, a foodie heaven with restaurants and cafes inspired by some of Britain’s leading chefs. 
All but the youngest two to four-year-olds club members can sign up for free lessons in the state of the art Cookery Club room, where there will also be paid-for family classes for over-8s and parents. 
Among P&O’s more family friendly excursions are Turkey’s Adaland Aquapark for itineraries that call at Kusadasi, and Oceanografic Marine Park for Western Mediterranean calling at Valencia. 
Dolphin and whale watching is also offered on some cruises, as well as family city tours. 
More information at www.pocruises.com
